description: a(n) is the smallest x such that p(x), p(x+1), ..., p(x+n-1) all have 10 as a primitive root, but p(x-1) and p(x+n) do not, where p(n)=A000040(n) is the n-th prime.
comments: A prime p has 10 as a primitive root iff the length of the period of the decimal expansion of 1/p is p-1.
mathematica: test[p_] := MultiplicativeOrder[10, p]===p-1; For[n=1, n<100, n++, a[n]=0]; v=4; While[True, For[n=1, test[Prime[v+n]], n++, Null]; If[a[n]==0, a[n]=v; Print["a(", n, ") = ", v]]; For[v+=n+1, !test[Prime[v]], v++, Null]]
author: _Jeff Burch_, Mar 23 2001
